data.title: The 14 best movies coming to Netflix in March
data.meta_description: Watch all "The Hunger Games" movies, Adam Sandler's new movie "Spaceman," and the classic comedy "Step Brothers," when they hit Netflix in March.
data.text:
This story is available exclusively to Business Insider subscribers. Become an Insider and start reading now. Have an account? .

Advertisement

'Spaceman' (March 1)

Adam Sandler's latest Netflix original movie is a change of pace for the comedian. In the sci-fi drama "Spaceman," Sandler plays Jakub, an astronaut traveling toward the edge of the solar system whose encounter with an alien spider, voiced by Paul Dano, helps him make sense of his earthly problems with his wife, played by Carey Mulligan.

'Beverly Hills Ninja' (March 1)

This silly comedy stars Chris Farley as a man raised by ninjas. Though he hardly has the talents of those who trained him, he somehow lands a mission in Beverly Hills to track down a murderer.

Advertisement

'Bonnie & Clyde' (March 1)

Arthur Penn's 1967 classic about the real-life Depression-era bank robbers Clyde Barrow and Bonnie Parker, played by Warren Beatty and Faye Dunaway, marked the start of the "New Hollywood" era in the movie industry.

Advertisement

'Devil in a Blue Dress' (March 1)

One of Denzel Washington's most underrated performances, here he plays Ezekiel "Easy" Rawlins, a World War II vet recently laid off who is offered a job by a private investigator to track down a woman.

The movie also marks a breakout performance for Don Cheadle, who plays Washington's hot-headed friend Mouse.

Advertisement

'Dumb and Dumber' (March 1)

This classic comedy stars Jim Carrey and Jeff Daniels as absent-minded friends who set out on a road trip.

Advertisement

'Fear' (March 1)

Mark Wahlberg and Reese Witherspoon star in this late-1990s thriller, which the "Fear" producer Brian Grazer once called "'Fatal Attraction' for teens."

Witherspoon plays Nicole, who falls for the charming David, played by Wahlberg. Eventually, Nicole and her parents, played by William Petersen and Amy Brenneman, realize that David is no good as he begins to terrorize them.

Advertisement

'Love & Basketball' (March 1)

If you're searching for a love story that doesn't turn psychotic, try the acclaimed directorial debut by Gina Prince-Bythewood, the director of "The Woman King."

Omar Epps and Sanaa Lathan play lifelong friends who love basketball. We follow their journey into college as their love for each other and the game begins to clash.

'National Lampoon’s Animal House' (March 1)

This raunchy look at a college fraternity made togas a campus tradition and John Belushi a comedy legend.

Advertisement

'Step Brothers' (March 1)

Arguably the greatest work in the collaboration between Will Ferrell and the director Adam McKay, Ferrell teams with John C. Reilly to play adult men who act like kids.

The comedy has become so beloved that all you have to say is "Prestige Worldwide" or "Catalina Wine Mixer" in public to generate laughter.

'Damsel' (March 8)

This Netflix original movie stars Millie Bobby Brown as Elodie, a noble who gets more than she bargained for when she marries the prince, played by Nick Robinson. Turns out, she's set to be sacrificed to repay an ancient debt. Now, the only way for Elodie to live is to battle a dragon.

Advertisement

'Irish Wish' (March 15)

In Lindsay Lohan's latest Netflix movie, she plays a woman whose dream guy is about to marry her best friend in Ireland. But after Lohan's character makes a wish on an ancient stone, she magically becomes the bride.

'Bodies Bodies Bodies' (March 20)

In this satirical horror movie, a group of friends plan a party during a hurricane, only to have it ruined when they start getting murdered. The ensemble cast, featuring Pete Davidson, Amandla Stenberg, Rachel Sennott, Maria Bakalova, and Lee Pace, dig into each other with biting wit as a murderer digs into them.

Advertisement

'Kill Bill Vol. 1' and '2' (March 31)

A tour de force performance by Uma Thurman tops Quentin Tarantino's love letter to the martial-arts genre. Thurman's character, only known as "The Bride," is out for revenge, seeking the people who tried to kill her on her wedding day.

All 'The Hunger Games' movies (March 31)

Sit back and take in all four movies in the franchise starring Jennifer Lawrence as the hero Katniss Everdeen: "The Hunger Games," "The Hunger Games: Catching Fire," "The Hunger Games: Mockingjay — Part 1," "The Hunger Games: Mockingjay — Part 2."
